column2: She looked out upon the dark-gray lines of the church tower, square and straight in the centre of the view, cutting against the deep blue transparent depths beyond, into which she gazed, and felt that she might gaze for ever, seeing at every moment some farther distance, and yet no sign of God!

column2: It seemed to her at the moment, as if the earth was more utterly desolate than if girt in by an iron dome, behind which there might be the ineffaceable peace and glory of the Almighty: those never-ending depths of space, in their still serenity, were more mocking to her than any material bounds could be--shutting in the cries of earth's sufferers, which now might ascend into that infinite splendour of vastness and be lost--lost for ever, before they reached His throne. In this mood her father came in unheard.

column2: She dared not go to meet him, and tell him what she had done all day, for fear of her mother's jealous annoyance. She heard him linger, as if awaiting her, or some sign of her; and she dared not stir; she saw by her mother's twitching lips, and changing colour, that she too was aware that her husband had returned.
column3: She dared not go to meet him, and tell him what she had done all day, for fear of her mother's jealous annoyance. She heard him linger, as if awaiting her, or some sign of her; and she dared not stir; she saw by her mother's twitching lips, and changing colour, that she too was aware that her husband had returned.

column2: Presently he opened the room-door, and stood there uncertain whether to come in. His face was gray and pale; he had a timid, fearful look in his eyes; something almost pitiful to see in a man's face; but that look of despondent uncertainty, of mental and bodily languor, touched his wife's heart.
column3: Presently he opened the room door, and stood there uncertain whether to come in. column2: She went to him, and threw herself on his breast, crying out--

column2: 'Oh! Richard, Richard, you should have told me sooner!'
column3: 'Oh! Richard, Richard, you should have told me sooner!'

column2: And then, in tears, Margaret left her, as she rushed up-stairs to throw herself on her bed, and hide her face in the pillows to stifle the hysteric sobs that would force their way at last, after the rigid self-control of the whole day.
column3: And then, in tears, Margaret left her, as she rushed up stairs to throw herself on her bed, and hide her face in the pillows to stifle the hysteric sobs that would force their way at last, after the rigid self control of the whole day.

column2: How long she lay thus she could not tell. She heard no noise, though the housemaid came in to arrange the room. The affrighted girl stole out again on tip-toe, and went and told Mrs. Dixon that Miss Hale was crying as if her heart would break: she was sure she would make herself deadly ill if she went on at that rate.
column3: How long she lay thus she could not tell. She heard no noise, though the housemaid came in to arrange the room. column2: In consequence of this, Margaret felt herself touched, and started up into a sitting posture; she saw the accustomed room, the figure of Dixon in shadow, as the latter stood holding the candle a little behind her, for fear of the effect on Miss Hale's startled eyes, swollen and blinded as they were.
column3: In consequence of this, Margaret felt herself touched, and started up into a sitting posture; she saw the accustomed room, the figure of Dixon in shadow, as the latter stood holding the candle a little behind her, for fear of the effect on Miss Hale's startled eyes, swollen and blinded as they were.

column2: 'Oh, Dixon!
column3: 'Oh, Dixon!

column2: I did not hear you come into the room!' said Margaret, resuming her trembling self-restraint. 'Is it very late?' continued she, lifting herself languidly off the bed, yet letting her feet touch the ground without fairly standing down, as she shaded her wet ruffled hair off her face, and tried to look as though nothing were the matter; as if she had only been asleep.
column3: I did not hear you come into the room!' said Margaret, resuming her trembling self restraint. 'Is it very late?' continued she, lifting herself languidly off the bed, yet letting her feet touch the ground without fairly standing down, as she shaded her wet ruffled hair off her face, and tried to look as though nothing were the matter; as if she had only been asleep.

column2: 'I hardly can tell what time it is,' replied Dixon, in an aggrieved tone of voice.
column3: 'I hardly can tell what time it is,' replied Dixon, in an aggrieved tone of voice.

column2: 'Since your mamma told me this terrible news, when I dressed her for tea, I've lost all count of time.
column3: 'Since your mamma told me this terrible news, when I dressed her for tea, I've lost all count of time.

column2: I'm sure I don't know what is to become of us all.
column3: I'm sure I don't know what is to become of us all.

column2: When Charlotte told me just now you were sobbing, Miss Hale, I thought, no wonder, poor thing!
column3: When Charlotte told me just now you were sobbing, Miss Hale, I thought, no wonder, poor thing!

column2: And master thinking of turning Dissenter at his time of life, when, if it is not to be said he's done well in the Church, he's not done badly after all.
column3: And master thinking of turning Dissenter at his time of life, when, if it is not to be said he's done well in the Church, he's not done badly after all.

column2: I had a cousin, miss, who turned Methodist preacher after he was fifty years of age, and a tailor all his life; but then he had never been able to make a pair of trousers to fit, for as long as he had been in the trade, so it was no wonder; but for master! as I said to missus, "What would poor Sir John have said?
column3: I had a cousin, miss, who turned Methodist preacher after he was fifty years of age, and a tailor all his life; but then he had never been able to make a pair of trousers to fit, for as long as he had been in the trade, so it was no wonder; but for master! as I said to missus, "What would poor Sir john have said?

column2: he never liked your marrying Mr. Hale, but if he could have known it would have come to this, he would have sworn worse oaths than ever, if that was possible!"'

column2: Dixon had been so much accustomed to comment upon Mr. Hale's proceedings to her mistress (who listened to her, or not, as she was in the humour), that she never noticed Margaret's flashing eye and dilating nostril.
column3: Dixon had been so much accustomed to comment upon mr Hale's proceedings to her mistress (who listened to her, or not, as she was in the humour), that she never noticed Margaret's flashing eye and dilating nostril.

column2: To hear her father talked of in this way by a servant to her face!
column3: To hear her father talked of in this way by a servant to her face!

column2: 'Dixon,' she said, in the low tone she always used when much excited, which had a sound in it as of some distant turmoil, or threatening storm breaking far away.
column3: 'Dixon,' she said, in the low tone she always used when much excited, which had a sound in it as of some distant turmoil, or threatening storm breaking far away.

column2: 'Dixon! you forget to whom you are speaking.' She stood upright and firm on her feet now, confronting the waiting-maid, and fixing her with her steady discerning eye.
column3: 'Dixon! you forget to whom you are speaking.' She stood upright and firm on her feet now, confronting the waiting maid, and fixing her with her steady discerning eye.

column2: 'I am Mr. Hale's daughter.

column2: Go!
column3: Go!

column2: You have made a strange mistake, and one that I am sure your own good feeling will make you sorry for when you think about it.'
column3: You have made a strange mistake, and one that I am sure your own good feeling will make you sorry for when you think about it.'

column2: Dixon hung irresolutely about the room for a minute or two.
column3: Dixon hung irresolutely about the room for a minute or two.

column2: Margaret repeated, 'You may leave me, Dixon.
column3: Margaret repeated, 'You may leave me, Dixon.

column2: I wish you to go.' Dixon did not know whether to resent these decided words or to cry; either course would have done with her mistress: but, as she said to herself, 'Miss Margaret has a touch of the old gentleman about her, as well as poor Master Frederick; I wonder where they get it from?' and she, who would have resented such words from any one less haughty and determined in manner, was subdued enough to say, in a half humble, half injured tone:
column3: I wish you to go.' column2: 'Mayn't I unfasten your gown, miss, and do your hair?'
column3: 'Mayn't I unfasten your gown, miss, and do your hair?'

column2: 'No! not to-night, thank you.' And Margaret gravely lighted her out of the room, and bolted the door.
column3: 'No! not to night, thank you.' And Margaret gravely lighted her out of the room, and bolted the door.

column2: From henceforth Dixon obeyed and admired Margaret.
column3: From henceforth Dixon obeyed and admired Margaret.

column2: She said it was because she was so like poor Master Frederick; but the truth was, that Dixon, as do many others, liked to feel herself ruled by a powerful and decided nature.
column3: She said it was because she was so like poor Master Frederick; but the truth was, that Dixon, as do many others, liked to feel herself ruled by a powerful and decided nature.

column2: Margaret needed all Dixon's help in action, and silence in words; for, for some time, the latter thought it her duty to show her sense of affront by saying as little as possible to her young lady; so the energy came out in doing rather than in speaking.
column3: Margaret needed all Dixon's help in action, and silence in words; for, for some time, the latter thought it her duty to show her sense of affront by saying as little as possible to her young lady; so the energy came out in doing rather than in speaking.

column2: A fortnight was a very short time to make arrangements for so serious a removal; as Dixon said, 'Any one but a gentleman--indeed almost any other gentleman--' but catching a look at Margaret's straight, stern brow just here, she coughed the remainder of the sentence away, and meekly took the horehound drop that Margaret offered her, to stop the 'little tickling at my chest, miss.' But almost any one but Mr. Hale would have had practical knowledge enough to see, that in so short a time it would be difficult to fix on any house in Milton-Northern, or indeed elsewhere, to which they could remove the furniture that had of necessity to be taken out of Helstone vicarage.

column2: Mrs. Hale, overpowered by all the troubles and necessities for immediate household decisions that seemed to come upon her at once, became really ill, and Margaret almost felt it as a relief when her mother fairly took to her bed, and left the management of affairs to her.
column3: mrs Hale, overpowered by all the troubles and necessities for immediate household decisions that seemed to come upon her at once, became really ill, and Margaret almost felt it as a relief when her mother fairly took to her bed, and left the management of affairs to her.

column2: Dixon, true to her post of body-guard, attended most faithfully to her mistress, and only emerged from Mrs. Hale's bed-room to shake her head, and murmur to herself in a manner which Margaret did not choose to hear.
column3: Dixon, true to her post of body guard, attended most faithfully to her mistress, and only emerged from mrs Hale's bed room to shake her head, and murmur to herself in a manner which Margaret did not choose to hear.

column2: For, the one thing clear and straight before her, was the necessity for leaving Helstone.
column3: For, the one thing clear and straight before her, was the necessity for leaving Helstone.

column2: Mr. Hale's successor in the living was appointed; and, at any rate, after her father's decision; there must be no lingering now, for his sake, as well as from every other consideration.

column2: Margaret, inexperienced as she was in all the necessary matter-of-fact business to be got through, did not know to whom to apply for advice.

column2: The cook and Charlotte worked away with willing arms and stout hearts at all the moving and packing; and as far as that went, Margaret's admirable sense enabled her to see what was best, and to direct how it should be done.

column2: Once a year, there was a long discussion between her aunt and Edith as to whether they should go to the Isle of Wight, abroad, or to Scotland; but at such times Margaret herself was secure of drifting, without any exertion of her own, into the quiet harbour of home.
column3: Once a year, there was a long discussion between her aunt and Edith as to whether they should go to the Isle of Wight, abroad, or to Scotland; but at such times Margaret herself was secure of drifting, without any exertion of her own, into the quiet harbour of home.

column2: 'I have hit upon such a beautiful plan.

column2: Look here--in Darkshire, hardly the breadth of my finger from Milton, is Heston, which I have often heard of from people living in the north as such a pleasant little bathing-place.

column2: 'Is Dixon to go with us?' asked Mr. Hale, in a kind of helpless dismay.

column2: 'But we shall have to put up with a very different way of living, I am afraid.

column2: To tell you the truth Margaret, I sometimes feel as if that woman gave herself airs.'
